This is the first of a short series of articles I have in mind. I'll expose the lessons we learned developing @yield v2.

I intend to fill a smart contracts education gap by targeting a skilled audience, and introduce design patterns that worked for me.
Finally, using fixed point prices introduces rounding errors. Skipping prices and dealing with amounts removes some of these precision losses.
At the same time, thinking about token amounts makes irrelevant how many decimals the tokens have. If you have worked with USDC or WBTC you know the headache that decimals are.
@yield We all think about token prices in our contracts. Thinking about token amounts instead reduces complexity by giving an immediate meaning to our variables.

When developing the oracle layer for @yield I learned one (1) thing that has helped me build more robust, scalable and precise smart contracts.
